MKT.name: Market Magnitude
MKT.description: Realistic capturable market in 3-5 years. Not hand-waving TAM but plausible revenue ceiling for a single company.

scale.9-10: $10B+ addressable, platform-scale outcome (log-scale, top quartile only)

CAP.name: Capture Feasibility
CAP.description: Can a seed-funded startup realistically capture meaningful share in 3-5 years? Measures actual capture mechanics, not hype.

scale.1-2: Incumbents own distribution, 24+ month sales cycles, regulatory blocks
scale.5-6: Mixed channels, some accessible, 6-12 month sales cycles
scale.7-8: Direct acquisition viable, PLG possible, 3-6 month cycles
scale.9-10: Greenfield with pull demand, viral/PLG, customers actively seeking

ECO.name: Unit Economics
ECO.description: Steady-state margin and capital efficiency. Architecture-driven — maps business model to known margin profile.

scale.5-6: Mixed model, 45-60% gross margins, some recurring revenue
scale.7-8: Software/SaaS, 65-80% gross margins, strong unit economics
scale.9-10: Pure software/data, 80%+ margins, near-zero marginal cost

VEL.name: Revenue Velocity
VEL.description: Speed from $0 to $5M ARR. Determines whether 3-5 year window produces markable outcome.

scale.1-2: 36+ months to first material revenue, deep-tech R&D
scale.3-4: 18-36 months, long enterprise sales or regulatory approvals
scale.5-6: 12-18 months, standard B2B SaaS sales cycle
scale.9-10: <6 months, viral/PLG with instant activation, pull demand

MOA.name: Moat Trajectory
MOA.description: Once you have traction, does the business get harder or easier to compete with? Measures 5-year defensibility arc.

scale.1-2: Commodity forever, anyone can replicate, no switching costs
scale.3-4: Moderate switching costs, relationship moat only
scale.5-6: Meaningful switching costs + some data effects, but displaceable
scale.7-8: Strong compounding moat — data flywheel, regulatory capture, multi-product lock-in
scale.9-10: Winner-take-most dynamics, data moat grows exponentially

models.name: Retail Media Network Platform
models.one_liner: Advertising platform built on retailer first-party data, transforming retail from margin business to media business. $69.3B market in 2026, growing 20% annually. Amazon (77% share) + Walmart Connect ($4.4B) dominate.
falsification_criteria: Cloud hyperscalers (AWS/Azure/GCP) build equivalent infrastructure as native features
Market fragments into point solutions rather than consolidating onto platforms
Retail footprint contraction accelerates beyond AI-optimization ability to offset
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
models.cla_rationale: Amazon controls 77% of retail media ($56B). First-party purchase data + retailer exclusivity = near-unbreakable moat. Enabling tech layer (Criteo, CitrusAd, Kevel) exists but is thin and commoditizable. Google Ads could aggregate mid-market but doesn't solve the retailer-owned data problem. Entry limited to ad-tech tools, not the network itself. DECOMPOSED: 3 sub-models spanning ACCESSIBLE, CONTESTED. OPP range [54.0 — 66.5]. See sub-models for layer-specific entry analysis.
models.vcr_rationale: Retail media $69B+ but Amazon controls 77%. Massive market, near-impossible capture at seed stage.
models.deep_dive_evidence: US retail media spending: $58.8B (2025) to $69.3B (2026), growing 20%/year. Amazon Ads at $56B, 77% market share. Walmart Connect $4.4B, up 27% YoY, +53% globally with Vizio acquisition. Retail media fundamentally changes retail economics: stores and logistics operate at near break-even, advertising generates profit margin. This is why Amazon can undercut on price -- they monetize traffic, not products. Mid-market retailers building their own networks (Kroger Precision Marketing, Target Roundel).

models.name: Climate Risk Analytics and Disclosure Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered climate risk modeling, scenario analysis, and regulatory disclosure platform for corporates and financial institutions — serving mandatory SEC and EU CSRD reporting requirements across 50,000+ affected companies
falsification_criteria: Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
Incumbent firms in Finance and Insurance successfully deploy equivalent AI internally
models.cla_rationale: Heuristic v3-14: arch=data_compounding, NAICS=52, with MO/MA differentiation and VD sector adjustment
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=data_compounding, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: The SEC's climate disclosure rule (adopted March 2024, partially stayed pending litigation but Scope 1/2 reporting proceeding) requires public companies to report greenhouse gas emissions, climate risk governance, and transition plans. The EU's CSRD is more aggressive — requiring 50,000+ companies (including non-EU companies with significant EU revenue) to report under European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS) starting 2024-2026 in phases. Together, these mandates create a structural requirement for climate risk analytics that did not exist 3 years ago. The climate risk analytics market is projected at $4.8B by 2029 (MarketsandMarkets, 22.3% CAGR). Current landscape: Persefoni (raised $101M) provides carbon accounting for SEC/CSRD compliance. Watershed (raised $100M, valued at $1.8B) serves enterprise carbon management. S&P Global, MSCI, and Moody's offer climate risk scoring but lack the granular physical risk modeling and disclosure automation that corporates need. The data moat opportunity: climate risk modeling requires integrating satellite imagery, weather data, supply chain mapping, emissions factors, and financial data into company-specific risk scores. Each client engagement generates proprietary risk data that improves models. Banks and insurers need portfolio-level climate risk aggregation for TCFD/ECB stress testing — JPMorgan alone has $3.4T in assets requiring climate risk assessment. The gap between regulatory requirement and corporate capability is enormous: Deloitte's 2025 climate survey found only 23% of affected companies have automated climate data collection, and 68% are relying on spreadsheets for CSRD reporting.

models.name: Post-Quantum Cryptography Migration Platform
models.one_liner: Enterprise migration platform for NIST post-quantum cryptographic standards — automated PKI inventory, cipher suite replacement, and compliance validation targeting the $3.2B PQC migration market by 2030 as harvest-now-decrypt-later threats accelerate government and financial sector deadlines
falsification_criteria: Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
Incumbent firms in Information successfully deploy equivalent AI internally
models.cla_rationale: Heuristic v3-14: arch=vertical_saas, NAICS=51, with MO/MA differentiation and VD sector adjustment
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=vertical_saas, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: NIST finalized three post-quantum cryptographic standards in August 2024 (FIPS 203 ML-KEM, FIPS 204 ML-DSA, FIPS 205 SLH-DSA), triggering the largest cryptographic migration since the SHA-1 to SHA-2 transition. The NSA's CNSA 2.0 timeline mandates PQC adoption for all national security systems by 2030, with software and firmware signing required by 2025. The harvest-now-decrypt-later threat — adversaries capturing encrypted data today to decrypt with future quantum computers — makes the timeline urgent for financial services, healthcare, and government. MarketsandMarkets projects the PQC market reaching $3.2B by 2030 from $310M in 2024 (43% CAGR). The core problem is discovery: large enterprises have 50,000-500,000+ cryptographic assets (certificates, keys, cipher suites) embedded across applications, APIs, and infrastructure with no centralized inventory. IBM, Thales, and Entrust are offering PQC toolkits but none provide automated end-to-end migration orchestration. SandboxAQ (spun out of Alphabet) raised $500M and is targeting this space. Estimated 85% of Fortune 500 companies have not begun PQC readiness assessment (Deloitte 2025 survey). Federal contractors face binding deadlines under OMB M-23-02 requiring cryptographic inventory by 2025 and migration plans by 2026.

models.name: AI Governance and Compliance Operating System
models.one_liner: Enterprise platform managing AI model inventory, risk assessment, bias monitoring, and regulatory compliance across US/EU/China regimes.
falsification_criteria: Cloud hyperscalers (AWS/Azure/GCP) build equivalent infrastructure as native features
Market fragments into point solutions rather than consolidating onto platforms
Professional licensing bodies restrict AI-assisted service delivery in regulated professions
Consumer and enterprise AI trust rises above 70% (Edelman), eliminating fear-friction demand
models.cla_rationale: Market is nascent ($309M→$15.8B projected, 51x). No dominant AI-native governance platform exists. Legacy compliance tools (ServiceNow, IBM) haven't pivoted to AI governance. Three diverging regulatory regimes (US/EU/China) prevent single-winner dynamics and reward specialized expertise. EU AI Act deadline (Aug 2026) is a hard forcing function. Fear-driven demand (46% adoption plateau) CREATES market rather than just filling it.
models.vcr_rationale: AI governance platform. Enterprise compliance, growing regulatory push, but immature buying process.

models.name: Warehouse Fulfillment Robotics Platform
models.one_liner: End-to-end warehouse automation (goods-to-person robots, automated sorting, AI pick-path optimization) for retail fulfillment centers. $181B market by 2031 at 31.6% CAGR.
falsification_criteria: Horizontal platform (Salesforce/Microsoft/Google) adds vertical-specific AI features matching specialist depth
Customer acquisition cost exceeds 18-month payback period in target segment
General merchandise retail consolidates to 3-4 dominant players, locking out new technology vendors
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
models.cla_rationale: Amazon Robotics (ex-Kiva) and Symbotic (Walmart) dominate. Capital + IP + installation lock-in form hard moats. Multi-layer stack (hardware AMR/AGV, pick-path AI, integration, maintenance) provides entry points. Humanoid robotics (Unitree, AgiBot, Figure) is a real disruption vector but 3-5 years from warehouse deployment. Open-source robot brains (Alibaba RynnBrain VLA) could democratize software layer. DECOMPOSED: 3 sub-models spanning ACCESSIBLE, CONTESTED. OPP range [50.5 — 66.5]. See sub-models for layer-specific entry analysis.
models.vcr_rationale: Warehouse robotics $181B by 2031 but requires massive capex. Hardware margins. Not seed-fundable at core.
models.deep_dive_evidence: Retail robotics growing from $20.1B (2024) to $181.1B (2031) at 31.6% CAGR. Symbotic acquired Walmart's Advanced Systems division for $200M. Humanoid robotics funding up 300% (v38-S40). AMR/AGV market $13.2B by 2026. NVIDIA Jetson T4000 ($1,999) makes robot compute cheaper than smartphones. Alibaba open-sourced RynnBrain VLA model (v38-S06). Physical AI is the next major platform after software AI.

models.name: Autonomous Drone Swarm Command Platform
models.one_liner: Software platform for orchestrating autonomous drone swarms in ISR and logistics, selling to NATO allies as SaaS-on-SIPR.
falsification_criteria: Cloud hyperscalers (AWS/Azure/GCP) build equivalent infrastructure as native features
Market fragments into point solutions rather than consolidating onto platforms
Reshoring momentum reverses as tariff policy changes eliminate onshoring economic rationale
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
models.cla_rationale: Defense procurement barriers, security clearances, ITAR restrictions severely limit entry. Anduril, Shield AI, L3Harris dominate. Classified tech and government relationships are hard moats. Commercial drone tech is cheaper and evolving faster — Ukraine conflict proves smaller companies can compete. AUKUS opens allied markets. Best entry through NATO allies or specific subsystems.
models.vcr_rationale: Autonomous drone swarms. Massive defense TAM but procurement barriers kill seed-stage capture.

models.name: Cybersecurity AI for Defense Networks
models.one_liner: AI-powered network defense and threat hunting platform purpose-built for CMMC 2.0 compliance across the 300K+ Defense Industrial Base.
falsification_criteria: Cloud hyperscalers (AWS/Azure/GCP) build equivalent infrastructure as native features
Market fragments into point solutions rather than consolidating onto platforms
Professional licensing bodies restrict AI-assisted service delivery in regulated professions
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
models.cla_rationale: Cyber market broadly is crowded (CrowdStrike, Palo Alto dominate enterprise). But defense-specific AI-native cybersecurity is less crowded. CMMC certification creates barrier-as-moat. Expanding attack surface + AI-generated attacks require AI defense. Defense budgets growing.
models.vcr_rationale: Defense cybersecurity. Big TAM but procurement kills velocity and capture.

models.name: AI Jobsite Safety Monitoring Platform
models.one_liner: Computer vision + wearable IoT platform that detects safety hazards in real-time (fall risk, PPE compliance, struck-by exposure) on construction jobsites -- addressing the $4.6B construction worker safety market by 2030 within the broader $24.3B AI in construction market
falsification_criteria: Open-source or foundation model alternatives eliminate proprietary data moat advantages
Data privacy regulations (state-level CCPA variants) restrict data aggregation business model
Construction labor shortage resolves through immigration reform, reducing automation urgency
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
models.cla_rationale: Construction safety is the strongest demand signal in contech -- OSHA fines doubled in 2023, EMR (experience modification rate) directly impacts insurance premiums and bidding eligibility. Newmetrix (acquired by Oracle 2023) and Smartvid.io (acquired by Newmetrix) validated the category. Current leaders include Versatile (crane monitoring), Triax (wearables), and various startups. Market openness is moderate-high because no single platform dominates across all safety vectors (fall protection, struck-by, PPE, housekeeping, trenching). Oracle/Newmetrix is enterprise-focused. The mid-market (200K+ firms) is largely unserved. Demand visibility is the highest of any construction AI category: every GC faces OSHA compliance, insurance pressure, and moral obligation.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=predictive_analytics, buyer=mid_enterprise, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $24300M
models.deep_dive_evidence: Construction is the deadliest major industry: 1,056 fatalities in 2023 (BLS), 200K+ non-fatal injuries. OSHA's 'Fatal Four' (falls 33.5%, struck-by 11.1%, electrocution 7.0%, caught-in/between 5.4%) are all detectable by computer vision. OSHA maximum penalties increased to $16,131 per serious violation and $161,323 per willful violation (2024 adjustment). The construction worker safety market: $3.2B (2024) to $4.6B (2030) at 6.0% CAGR (GlobeNewswire/ResearchAndMarkets). AI-specific safety solutions growing at 30.5% CAGR within this market (Grand View Research). Insurance incentive: a single fatality costs $5M+ in direct costs; EMR impacts persist for 3 years on all bids. AI safety platforms (camera-based + wearable) can reduce recordable incidents 40-60% based on pilot data from Newmetrix, Smartvid.io, and Suffolk Construction deployments. Pricing: $2-5K/month per active jobsite for camera-based monitoring, $5-15/month per wearable per worker.

models.name: Infrastructure Inspection AI & Drone Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered drone and sensor platform for bridge, road, and utility infrastructure inspection -- replacing dangerous manual inspections in the $38.2B drone inspection market by 2030, with the US infrastructure backlog creating $2.6T in needed repairs (ASCE)
falsification_criteria: Robotics hardware costs remain above adoption threshold for target customer segment
Regulatory approval for autonomous operation takes 3+ years longer than projected
Construction labor shortage resolves through immigration reform, reducing automation urgency
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
models.cla_rationale: Infrastructure inspection is the strongest convergence point in construction: (1) IIJA mandates inspection of 45,000+ structurally deficient bridges, (2) manual inspection is dangerous (inspector fatalities, lane closures causing accidents), (3) inspector workforce is aging and shrinking, (4) drone + AI technology is mature enough for deployment. Current players: DroneUp, Skydio (raised $750M, US-made drones for defense/infrastructure), Flyability (confined space), Gecko Robotics (wall-climbing robots for utilities), and various DOT-specific solutions. Market openness is moderate: Skydio dominates the hardware layer for US government use (Chinese drone ban benefits US manufacturers). The AI ANALYSIS layer (identifying cracks, corrosion, deformation from drone imagery) is where the value concentrates and where competition is fragmented. Demand visibility is extreme: $2.6T infrastructure backlog (ASCE 2025 Report Card) + IIJA spending mandate.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=autonomous_systems, buyer=enterprise, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $2600000M
models.deep_dive_evidence: US infrastructure condition: ASCE 2025 Infrastructure Report Card grades US infrastructure C- overall, with $2.6T investment gap. 45,000+ structurally deficient bridges (7.5% of total). 40% of roads in poor or mediocre condition. 7,500 dam safety deficiencies. IIJA: $110B for roads and bridges, $55B for water, $65B for broadband -- all requiring inspection capacity. Current manual bridge inspection: $5-25K per bridge, requires lane closures (costing $50K+/day in economic impact), and exposes inspectors to fall risk. Drone inspection: $1-5K per bridge, no lane closure, higher-resolution data capture. Global drone inspection and monitoring market: $16.4B (2024) to $38.2B (2030) at 15.1% CAGR (ResearchAndMarkets). AI-specific drone analysis: $821M (2025) to $2.75B (2030) at 27.4% CAGR. The FAA BVLOS (beyond visual line of sight) waiver program is expanding, enabling autonomous long-range inspections. Skydio's $750M raise and US government contracts validate the hardware layer. The AI layer (automated crack detection, corrosion measurement, structural deformation analysis) is where the most defensible value lies -- each inspection adds training data that improves detection accuracy.

models.name: Sports Betting Data Intelligence & Compliance Platform
models.one_liner: Real-time sports data feeds, odds optimization, and responsible gambling compliance infrastructure for the $18B US sports betting market expanding across 39 legalized states
falsification_criteria: Sports betting legalization stalls — remaining 11 states (including California, Texas) fail to legalize, capping the addressable market
Sportradar and Genius Sports vertically integrate compliance features, eliminating the standalone compliance platform opportunity
Federal regulation preempts state-level requirements, simplifying compliance to the point where operators build in-house
models.cla_rationale: Market Openness is moderate (5): the data feed layer is dominated by Sportradar and Genius Sports (duopoly). But the compliance and responsible gambling technology layer is nascent — no dominant platform exists for multi-state regulatory compliance automation. GeoComply (geolocation compliance) proved the regulatory infrastructure category at $1B+ valuation. Moat Advantage is very strong (9): regulatory certification creates a 12-24 month barrier to entry per state. Once embedded in an operator's compliance stack, switching requires re-certification and regulatory approval — the strongest moat type in any sector. Value Density is high (8): compliance is non-negotiable — operators face license revocation for violations. Pricing of $50-200K/year per state per operator is justified by the alternative (losing a $100M+ state license). Demand Visibility is proven (9): 39 states with active licensing requirements, 20+ operators per state, and regulatory frameworks getting MORE complex, not less.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=regulatory_moat_builder, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW data: NAICS 7132 (Gambling Industries) has 4,195 establishments employing 116,263 workers at $954/week ($49,628 annual), with employment growing 8.3% YoY. The US sports betting market was $17.94B in 2024 (Grand View Research), growing at 10.9% CAGR. Handle (total amount wagered) exceeded $157B in FY2025, with 20% of US adults placing sports bets (up from 12% in 2023). Sports betting is now legal in 39 states plus DC. The infrastructure opportunity is the data and compliance layer BENEATH the consumer-facing sportsbooks. Sportradar processes 1.5B+ data points per second. The sports data oligopoly (Sportradar, Genius Sports, Stats Perform) powers the entire ecosystem. But the COMPLIANCE layer is under-built: responsible gambling regulations are tightening across jurisdictions, with each state imposing different requirements for self-exclusion programs, bet limits, advertising restrictions, and problem gambling detection. A multi-state operator must comply with 39 different regulatory frameworks simultaneously. iGaming (online casino) adds another dimension: $8.41B revenue in 2024 across 7 active states, growing 28.7% YoY. As more states legalize iGaming, the compliance complexity multiplies. The regulatory moat is real: compliance infrastructure that handles multi-state responsible gambling mandates, real-time bet monitoring for suspicious activity, and automated regulatory reporting creates deep defensibility — regulators approve specific technology stacks, and switching requires re-certification.

models.name: Defense AI/ML Intelligence Fusion Platform
models.one_liner: Multi-source intelligence fusion using LLMs to synthesize SIGINT/HUMINT/OSINT/GEOINT into actionable briefs at 100x analyst throughput.
falsification_criteria: Cloud hyperscalers (AWS/Azure/GCP) build equivalent infrastructure as native features
Market fragments into point solutions rather than consolidating onto platforms
Professional licensing bodies restrict AI-assisted service delivery in regulated professions
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
models.cla_rationale: Palantir dominates ($2.65B revenue, 90%+ of classified analytics). Clearance requirements severe. Government relationships deeply entrenched. Palantir's data moat + classified environment access = very strong moats. Only entry is through very specific niches (tactical-edge fusion for small units) or allied nations. Open-source LLMs could democratize some fusion but classified data handling limits this severely. DECOMPOSED: 1 sub-models spanning ACCESSIBLE. OPP range [61.0 — 61.0]. See sub-models for layer-specific entry analysis.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=platform, buyer=multi, frag=7, tam_source=sector $1200000M→$12000M addressable, defense penalty

models.name: AI-Native Restaurant Operating System
models.one_liner: Unified AI-powered back-office platform for independent restaurants — scheduling, inventory, accounting, vendor management in one system targeting the $14.7B restaurant management software market by 2030
falsification_criteria: Horizontal platform (Salesforce/Microsoft/Google) adds vertical-specific AI features matching specialist depth
Customer acquisition cost exceeds 18-month payback period in target segment
Minimum wage increases compress restaurant margins beyond AI savings capacity
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
models.cla_rationale: Toast dominates restaurant tech at 120K+ locations but charges $69-$165/mo per terminal plus payment processing — leaving massive room for AI-native challengers that compress multiple point solutions. Market Openness is moderate (6): Toast, Square, Clover have distribution but independents remain deeply underserved (only 38% use digital ordering). Moat Advantage is strong (7): data compounding across scheduling, inventory, and accounting creates switching costs once embedded — the restaurant OS becomes the system of record. Value Density is moderate (5): $200-400/mo ARPU from small restaurants with high churn (56-day avg employee tenure mirrors owner turnover). Demand Visibility is proven (9): 611K restaurants with <$3K/year tech spend is the most visible unmet demand in any sector. The gap between chain sophistication and independent capability is the largest technology adoption gap in the US economy.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=vertical_saas, buyer=smb_mid, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $14700M
models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW data confirms 610,970 restaurant and eating places establishments (NAICS 7225) employing 10.95M workers at $502/week ($26,097 annual) — a Baumol score of 0.36, the lowest in the economy. Grand View Research projects the restaurant management software market reaching $14.7B by 2030 from $5.79B in 2024 (17.4% CAGR). The core thesis: independent restaurants (90%+ of establishments) spend less than $3,000/year on technology versus chains spending $15,000-50,000+/year per location. This $12-47K gap per location across 550K+ independents represents a $6.6-25.8B annual technology spend gap. Toast proved the category ($1.2B+ revenue) but charges payment processing spreads on top of SaaS fees — the AI-native entrant can offer a unified OS (scheduling via AI demand prediction, inventory via computer vision waste tracking, accounting via transaction auto-categorization, vendor management via price comparison) at lower total cost by monetizing the software layer rather than payment spreads. The 2022-2023 QCEW data shows establishments growing 2.5% YoY while employment grows 3.5% — new restaurants are opening and hiring, validating continued demand. Average workers per establishment of 17.9 means the buyer is a small-business owner who needs simplicity, not enterprise features.

models.name: Fitness & Recreation Center Operating System
models.one_liner: AI-native gym management platform unifying member management, scheduling, retention prediction, and revenue optimization for the 44K-establishment fitness center market with 50%+ annual churn
falsification_criteria: ABC Fitness/Glofox or Mindbody achieve 40%+ market penetration through acquisition roll-up, closing the independent gym management gap
Planet Fitness and other franchise models continue capturing share, reducing the independent gym establishment count below 30K
Gym member churn proves resistant to AI intervention — members leave for lifestyle/motivation reasons that software cannot address
models.cla_rationale: Market Openness is strong (7): despite Mindbody and ABC Fitness consolidation, no single platform has >15% share of 44K establishments. The market is so fragmented that it supports multiple winners. Boutique studios (Barry's, Orangetheory, F45) have different needs than budget gyms (Planet Fitness, Crunch) and traditional health clubs — creating segmentation opportunities. Moat Advantage is moderate (6): member data and billing integrations create switching costs, but the core product (member management, scheduling) risks commoditization — differentiation comes from AI-powered retention prediction and revenue optimization. Value Density is moderate (5): $200-500/month ARPU from price-sensitive small businesses — fitness center operators watch every dollar. Demand Visibility is proven (9): 44K establishments each needing management software is the definition of visible demand. The ABC/Glofox ($200M+) and Mindbody/ClassMonkey acquisitions confirm category value.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=vertical_saas, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW data: NAICS 713940 (Fitness and Recreational Sports Centers) has 44,125 establishments employing 620,848 workers at $414/week ($21,530 annual) — the LOWEST average pay in NAICS 71 and among the lowest in the entire economy. This is the employment center of the arts/entertainment/recreation sector: 621K workers across 44K locations, with employment growing 8.1% YoY and establishments growing 2.9%. The gym management software market was valued at $16.88B in 2024, projected to reach $38.05B by 2032 at 14.3% CAGR (Verified Market Research). The sector's structural problem is CHURN: industry average member churn exceeds 50% annually. At Planet Fitness pricing ($10-25/mo), even small churn rate improvements translate to massive revenue impact. AI can predict churn 30-60 days before cancellation based on visit frequency decay, class booking patterns, and engagement signals — enabling proactive retention interventions. The competitive landscape is consolidating rapidly: ABC Fitness Solutions acquired Glofox for EUR 200M+; Mindbody acquired ClassMonkey (15K+ clients) in February 2025. But extreme fragmentation (44.1K establishments) means no player has dominant share. The average fitness center has 14.1 workers — these are small businesses needing integrated operations, not enterprise software. The AI opportunity: automated class scheduling based on demand prediction, dynamic pricing for off-peak hours, personalized member engagement via AI, equipment maintenance prediction via IoT, and integrated billing/payment processing. 68.9M Americans now have gym memberships — an all-time high — validating sustained demand.

models.name: EU AI Act Compliance Automation Engine
models.one_liner: Automated compliance platform that continuously monitors AI systems against EU AI Act's risk-based requirements -- going beyond V3-GEO-004's advisory model to embed compliance-as-code into AI deployment pipelines for the 450M-person EU market
models.sector_name: Software Publishers — EU AI Regulatory Compliance
falsification_criteria: Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
Incumbent firms in Software Publishers — EU AI Regulatory Compliance successfully deploy equivalent AI internally
models.cla_rationale: Heuristic v3-14: arch=compliance_automation, NAICS=51, with MO/MA differentiation and VD sector adjustment
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=compliance_automation, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: EU AI Act: entered force Feb 2025, prohibited AI practices banned immediately, high-risk system requirements phased in through 2027. Fines up to 7% of global revenue for non-compliance (vs GDPR's 4%). Every company deploying AI in EU needs: (1) risk classification per system, (2) conformity assessment for high-risk, (3) transparency documentation, (4) human oversight protocols, (5) continuous monitoring for performance drift and bias. Current compliance is manual (legal teams + consultants at $500-1000/hour). Automated compliance-as-code could reduce cost 80-90%. TAM: every company deploying AI in EU = potentially 100K+ organizations in first 3 years. SOC 2 compliance automation precedent: Vanta reached $2.5B valuation automating a much simpler compliance requirement. EU AI Act compliance is 10x more complex than SOC 2. Revenue model: SaaS per AI system monitored ($500-5000/month per system, depending on risk tier).

models.name: Skilled Trades Workforce Marketplace & Upskilling Platform
models.one_liner: Two-sided marketplace connecting 2M+ specialty trade workers with 540K contractor firms, with embedded skills verification, credential management, and AR-powered upskilling -- addressing the 650K worker shortage in a $130B temporary staffing market where 17.2% of gig workers are in construction
falsification_criteria: Supply-side participants disintermediate the platform through direct relationships
Network effects fail to materialize due to low transaction frequency in the sector
Construction labor shortage resolves through immigration reform, reducing automation urgency
Immigration policy reversal fills labor gaps, reducing demographic pressure on automation
models.cla_rationale: No dominant digital marketplace exists for construction labor. Current solutions: (1) Traditional staffing agencies (Tradesmen International, $1.5B+ revenue; PeopleReady) -- high-fee, low-tech. (2) Workrise (formerly RigUp, $500M+ raised) -- primarily oil & gas, expanding to construction. (3) Instawork, Wonolo -- general gig, not construction-specific. (4) Hireup (construction-focused, early). The gap is a construction-native platform with: credential verification (licenses, OSHA cards, drug tests), skill-matching (an electrician is not a plumber), project-based scheduling (not gig-by-gig), and embedded upskilling (AR training for new certifications). Market openness is high because traditional staffing agencies charge 30-50% markup and the 'Uber for construction workers' has not been built. Demand visibility is the highest possible: 650K unfilled positions is not a forecast, it is a measured gap.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=marketplace, buyer=multi, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $130000M
models.deep_dive_evidence: Construction workforce crisis by the numbers: 650K+ unfilled positions (Feb 2026 estimate based on AGC survey + BLS JOLTS data). 77% of firms report difficulty filling hourly craft positions (AGC 2025 Workforce Survey). Average construction worker age 42.5 and rising. Net annual deficit: ~100K workers/year (retirements exceed new entrants). 24% of construction workforce is foreign-born (Pew Research), concentrated in residential (30%+) -- directly exposed to immigration enforcement. Electrician shortage: 80K+ nationally (IBEW). HVAC technician shortage: 45K+. CSIS (Jan 2026): US needs 140K additional skilled trade workers by 2030 just for clean energy and data center construction. Traditional staffing agencies charge 30-50% markup; digital marketplace could reduce to 15-20% while improving matching speed from days to hours. Credential management is a massive pain point: the average specialty contractor carries 15-25 different licenses, certifications, and insurance documents that must be current for each project. An integrated marketplace with embedded credential verification, AI skill-matching, and AR upskilling modules creates a 3-sided platform (workers, contractors, training providers).

models.deep_dive_evidence: US industrial distribution is a $500B+ market with extreme fragmentation: 100K+ distributors, top 50 hold <25% combined share. The remaining ~90% of market is served by independent distributors averaging $5-15M in revenue and 15-50 employees. The Silver Tsunami is the defining catalyst: NAW Industrial Distribution Survey (2024) found 67% of owners over 55 have no documented succession plan. EBITDA multiples for independent distributors: 5-7x for $5-15M revenue, 7-9x for $15-50M. A rollup deploying standardized technology (unified ERP, AI demand forecasting, dynamic pricing, route optimization) can generate 200-400bps EBITDA expansion per acquired location within 18-24 months. Evidence: Winsupply (HVAC/plumbing, 700+ locations, $7B revenue) and SRS Distribution (roofing, $10B+, acquired by Home Depot for $18.25B in 2024) prove the model at scale. AI-specific impact: McKinsey estimates AI-driven demand forecasting improves inventory turns 15-25% and reduces stockouts 20-30% in distribution. At $500B market with 4% EBITDA, even 1% market share capture at improved margins generates $25M+ EBITDA.

models.name: AI-Optimized Liquid Cooling for Data Centers
models.one_liner: Intelligent direct-to-chip and immersion liquid cooling systems for AI data centers — replacing air cooling that cannot handle 120kW+ GPU racks, serving a $12.5B data center cooling market growing at 20% CAGR as AI compute density doubles annually
falsification_criteria: Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
Incumbent firms in Manufacturing — Electronics successfully deploy equivalent AI internally
models.cla_rationale: Heuristic v3-14: arch=hardware_ai, NAICS=33, with MO/MA differentiation and VD sector adjustment
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=hardware_ai, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: AI data center power density is outstripping air cooling physics. NVIDIA's Blackwell B200 GPU draws 1,000W per chip; a rack of 8 GPUs with networking and compute overhead reaches 100-150kW per rack — versus 15-25kW for traditional server racks. Air cooling physically cannot remove 100kW+ from a standard 42U rack without unacceptable airflow velocities and temperature differentials. This is not a preference — it is a thermodynamic constraint. The data center cooling market was $9.2B in 2024 and is projected to reach $25.5B by 2030 (Mordor Intelligence, 18.3% CAGR), with liquid cooling specifically reaching $12.5B. Three architectures compete: direct-to-chip (cold plates on CPUs/GPUs with liquid loops — deployed by CoolIT Systems at 4M+ nodes), rear-door heat exchangers (retrofit for existing racks), and full immersion (submerging servers in dielectric fluid — GRC, LiquidCool Solutions). Microsoft deployed liquid cooling across Azure AI data centers in 2024. Google uses liquid cooling for TPU pods. Meta is transitioning to liquid cooling for GPU clusters. NVIDIA mandates liquid cooling capability for Blackwell-based systems. The AI optimization layer is the differentiation: intelligent coolant flow control that adapts to GPU workload patterns (LLM inference has different thermal profiles than training), predictive maintenance using vibration and temperature sensors, and energy optimization that can reduce PUE from 1.3 (air) to 1.05-1.10 (liquid). CoolIT Systems (private, profitable) is the market leader in direct-to-chip but serves primarily hyperscalers — the enterprise and colocation segments remain underserved. Vertiv ($VRT, stock up 400%+ in 2024) and Schneider Electric are developing liquid cooling products but are not yet shipping at scale. The urgency is extreme: data center capacity is the binding constraint on AI scaling, and cooling is the binding constraint on density.

models.name: GLP-1 Patient Management and Outcomes Platform

models.deep_dive_evidence: GLP-1 receptor agonists (semaglutide/Wegovy, tirzepatide/Zepbound) represent the most significant pharmaceutical category expansion since statins. IQVIA data shows 9M+ active GLP-1 prescriptions in Q4 2024, with Morgan Stanley projecting 30M+ US patients by 2028 as Medicare coverage expands and supply constraints ease. Combined Wegovy + Zepbound revenue is projected to exceed $40B globally in 2025. The patient management gap is stark: GLP-1 patients experience significant side effects (nausea in 44%, muscle loss of 25-40% of weight lost, gallbladder events in 1.5%), require dosing titration over 16-20 weeks, need nutritional guidance to preserve lean mass, and face indefinite treatment duration with high discontinuation rates (50-70% stop within 1 year per real-world data from Truveta). Yet no dedicated patient management platform exists — patients rely on generic telehealth (Ro, Hims) for prescriptions and receive minimal ongoing support. The opportunity: a SaaS platform sold to health systems, employer wellness programs, and GLP-1 manufacturers that tracks patient outcomes, optimizes dosing schedules using real-world evidence, integrates CGM and body composition data, and reduces the $15,000+/year drug cost through improved adherence and reduced adverse events. Employer interest is surging: JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs, and major self-insured employers are adding GLP-1 coverage but need tools to manage $500M+ annual pharmacy spend on these drugs. Digital health companies Calibrate and Found focus on prescribing, not outcomes management — the post-prescription journey is unserved.

Layer 3 -- the middleware that lets a fleet operator run a mixed fleet of human-driven and autonomous trucks, manage transfer hub handoffs, and optimize AV utilization -- is the opportunity. Transfer hubs needed every 200-400 miles for driver handoff. Mixed fleet management is the transition-period software problem: most fleets will run 10-30% autonomous, 70-90% human for 5+ years. models.name: Energy Code & Sustainability Compliance Platform for Construction

models.cla_rationale: Energy code compliance is increasingly mandatory and increasingly complex. Current tools: (1) EnergyPlus (DOE, free, complex), (2) REScheck/COMcheck (DOE, basic compliance), (3) IES VE, eQUEST (commercial energy modeling, $10K+/year), (4) Autodesk Insight (integrated with Revit but limited), (5) cove.tool ($30M raised, performance-based building design). No single platform connects energy code compliance to permit submission to sustainability certification to embodied carbon tracking. The fragmentation of energy codes across jurisdictions (some states on IECC 2021, others on 2024, California on Title 24) creates complexity that AI can simplify. 70% of firms in developed regions already use software for green building compliance -- the question is whether a new platform can consolidate the workflow. Demand visibility is high: every new building must comply with energy codes, and codes are tightening every 3 years.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=compliance_automation, buyer=mid_enterprise, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $17520M
models.deep_dive_evidence: Building sector consumes 40% of US energy. Building codes are the primary policy lever for reducing building energy consumption. IECC 2024 (adopted by 12 states as of Feb 2026) requires 15-25% energy improvement over 2021 baseline, including: mandatory blower door testing, continuous insulation, high-efficiency HVAC, and for commercial buildings, automated lighting controls and energy recovery ventilation. California Title 24 (2025 cycle) mandates all-electric new construction in many zones. NYC LL97 imposes carbon penalties on existing buildings >25,000 SF starting 2024 (up to $268/ton CO2). 9 states mandate heat pumps in new residential. Embodied carbon: Portland, Vancouver, and LEED v5 now require lifecycle carbon assessment of construction materials. Building code compliance market: $8.2B (2023) to $17.52B (2032) at 8.8% CAGR. Green building certification market growing at 11.2% CAGR. cove.tool ($30M raised) has proven the 'performance-based design' category. The integration opportunity: a single platform that (1) identifies applicable energy codes by jurisdiction, (2) runs automated energy modeling on building designs, (3) checks compliance and generates required documentation, (4) tracks embodied carbon in material selections, (5) generates LEED/WELL/ENERGY STAR documentation. For residential builders (1.1M workers, 225K firms), energy code compliance is the FASTEST-GROWING source of project complexity and delay.

Digital twin in construction: $64.9B (2025) to $155.0B (2030) at 19.0% CAGR (NextMSC). BIM adoption is ~75% on commercial projects but only ~30% on residential. The lifecycle operations market (building management using the as-built digital twin) extends the TAM into facilities management ($1.1T globally).

However, most solutions are MONITORING-only (alerting after temperature excursion). The AI opportunity is PREDICTIVE: predicting temperature excursions BEFORE they happen (based on door open/close patterns, ambient temperature, load configuration, equipment age) and automatically triggering corrective actions. FSMA 204 traceability requirements create compliance automation opportunity. MO is 6 because Sensitech and Carrier have strong pharma positions. But food cold chain (70% of market) is underserved by pharma-grade solutions.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=iot_platform, buyer=mid_enterprise, frag=5, tam_source=parsed $109800M
models.deep_dive_evidence: US cold chain: $91.1B market (2025). $35B+ annual food waste attributed to cold chain failures. FDA FSMA 204 food traceability rule: requires end-to-end digital tracking of high-risk foods from farm to retail. Enforcement expanding through 2026. Temperature excursions cause 10-15% of pharmaceutical product losses ($15-35B globally). GLP-1 drugs (Ozempic, Mounjaro) require 36-46F storage -- $50B+ market creating cold chain demand surge. Biologics/mRNA vaccines require -70C storage, driving deep-frozen segment growth. Current cold chain monitoring: 60% still use single-use data loggers (no real-time visibility). Only 15% use predictive analytics. The gap between monitoring (what HAPPENED) and prediction (what WILL happen) is the AI opportunity. A reefer truck breakdown costs $5-25K per load in spoiled product. Predicting the breakdown 4 hours earlier (based on compressor vibration, condenser pressure, ambient temperature) saves the entire load.

models.name: AI-Native Wholesale Procurement Intelligence Platform
models.one_liner: Aggregate wholesale transaction data across 400K+ distributors to build the Bloomberg Terminal of B2B trade — pricing intelligence, demand signals, and supply chain mapping for $6T in wholesale flows

falsification_criteria: If distributors refuse to share transaction data even anonymized — competitive sensitivity may block data ingestion at the 10K+ transaction threshold
If Amazon Business builds wholesale pricing transparency as a feature, commoditizing the data layer
If incumbent ERP vendors (SAP, Oracle, Epicor, Infor) add sufficient pricing intelligence features to their distribution modules, eliminating standalone demand
models.cla_rationale: Market is open — no wholesale pricing intelligence platform exists at scale. Moat advantage is the strongest of any model in this deep dive: data network effects mean the first platform to aggregate 1M+ transactions becomes nearly impossible to displace. Value chain depth is significant: pricing data, demand forecasting, supplier scoring, risk alerts, and market reports represent 5+ monetizable layers. Demand visibility is moderate — distributors recognize the need for pricing intelligence but may resist sharing their own data to create it.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=data_compounding, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: Wholesale trade generates $6T+ in annual transaction volume across 400K+ establishments, yet pricing intelligence remains opaque. Unlike public equities (Bloomberg, $12B revenue) or commodities (Platts/OPIS for petroleum), most B2B wholesale pricing is negotiated bilaterally with no transparent market. Distributors maintain proprietary price books with 50K-500K SKUs, updated manually on spreadsheets or legacy ERP systems. The data compounding thesis: start as an AI-powered procurement tool (price comparison, vendor scoring, demand forecasting) for mid-market distributors. Each transaction processed reveals: (1) real-time pricing across product categories, (2) regional demand patterns, (3) supplier lead time and reliability data, (4) seasonal and cyclical demand curves. At 10K transactions: useful procurement tool. At 100K: predictive pricing intelligence. At 1M+: the definitive B2B wholesale market data platform. Precedent: Faire ($12.4B valuation, wholesale marketplace for independent retail) proved B2B wholesale platforms can reach massive scale. But Faire is retail-wholesale; the industrial/commercial wholesale intelligence layer is unbuilt. ZoomInfo ($6B+ revenue, B2B data for sales) proves enterprise data compounding can reach massive scale.

models.name: Municipal Digital Permitting & Zoning Automation Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered platform automating building permit review, zoning compliance checking, and inspection scheduling for 19,500+ US municipal jurisdictions — reducing the average commercial permit from 6-12 months to 2-4 months within the $6.3B digital permitting market

models.falsification_criteria: If Accela or Tyler Technologies successfully launches AI plan review that satisfies municipal customers, consolidating the fragmented market before challengers scale. If housing construction slowdown reduces permit volume, decreasing urgency for permitting modernization. If state preemption of local zoning authority reduces the number of jurisdictions making independent permitting decisions.
models.cla_rationale: The digital permitting market is ACCESSIBLE due to extreme fragmentation: 19,500 municipal jurisdictions, each with independent purchasing. No single vendor has >5% market share. Existing players: Accela ($200M+ revenue, legacy on-premise being pushed to cloud), Tyler Technologies (EnerGov — included in broader Tyler suite), OpenGov ($150M+, cloud-native budgeting + permitting), PermitFlow (YC startup, ~200 municipal deployments), GovBuilt (cloud permitting for smaller municipalities). MO is 7 because no dominant player and thousands of municipalities still use paper/PDF. MA is 7 because AI plan review models trained on local building codes (each municipality has unique amendments to ICC codes) create local moats. DV is 9 because every builder, developer, and homeowner experiences permit friction — demand is universal and visceral. The NIMBY/YIMBY political dynamic creates additional urgency: housing supply advocates pushing for faster permitting.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=vertical_saas, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: 19,502 municipal jurisdictions in the US, each responsible for building permits, zoning compliance, and inspections. The permitting process is the single largest government friction point for the private sector: NAHB estimates regulatory costs (including permitting delays) account for 23.8% of single-family home prices ($93,870 on a $394,300 home). Average time for a commercial building permit: 6-12 months. Residential: 2-4 months. Each permit application involves plan review against 50+ code sections (structural, fire, electrical, plumbing, mechanical, energy, accessibility, zoning). Plan review is 90%+ a code-compliance-checking exercise — exactly the kind of rule-based cognitive task where AI excels. AI plan review (companies like Novade, Autodesk, TestFit) can check code compliance in hours vs weeks. Inspection scheduling optimization (using ML to predict inspection readiness and route inspectors efficiently) can increase inspector productivity 30-40%. Current state: ~20% of US jurisdictions have any digital permitting. 80% still use paper applications, PDF plan submissions reviewed on screen, and manual scheduling. The housing affordability crisis creates political pressure for faster permitting. California (SB 423), Minnesota (statewide zoning reform), and 15+ states have passed legislation to streamline local permitting. Each legislative mandate creates demand for technology to implement compliance.

models.name: Commercial Earth Observation Analytics

falsification_criteria: Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

models.deep_dive_evidence: The earth observation data and services market reached $6.1B in 2024 and is projected to hit $9.4B by 2028 (Euroconsult, 14% CAGR). Critically, the commercial segment now exceeds the defense/intelligence segment for the first time — agriculture, insurance, energy, finance, and infrastructure monitoring collectively represent 60%+ of demand. Planet Labs ($PL, ~$180M annual revenue) provides daily global 3m imagery from 200+ satellites but generates only basic analytics. The value gap: raw satellite imagery is abundant and commoditizing; AI-derived insights are scarce and high-value. Specific verticals demonstrate this: crop yield prediction (Descartes Labs, Gro Intelligence) commands $5-50/acre from commodity traders and insurers; infrastructure monitoring (Orbital Insight, HawkEye 360) charges $50-500K/year for pipeline and power line surveillance; deforestation monitoring commands $100K+ per engagement from ESG-mandated corporations. The analytics layer has better unit economics than the satellite layer — Planet Labs has -10% operating margins despite $180M revenue, while analytics providers operate at 60-80% gross margins with no space hardware risk. The data compounding advantage: AI models trained on multi-year, multi-spectral satellite archives with ground-truth validation (actual crop yields, confirmed insurance claims, verified deforestation) improve continuously. SAR (synthetic aperture radar) data from Capella Space and ICEYE adds all-weather, day-night capability. The CHIPS Act and ITAR reform are enabling US commercial earth observation exports that were previously restricted. Maxar's $6.4B acquisition by Advent International (2023) validates category value at the asset level.

Value density is strong: mid-market employers (100-5,000 hourly workers) spend $50-500K/year on workforce management. models.deep_dive_evidence: The global workforce management market is growing from $8.4B in 2025 to $13.0B by 2030 at 9.2% CAGR (MarketsandMarkets). The US has 80M+ hourly workers (BLS), representing 55% of the workforce. NAICS 56 directly employs 9.4M of these workers and places millions more through staffing agencies. The compliance landscape is increasingly complex: predictive scheduling laws (requiring advance notice of schedules, penalty pay for changes) now exist in 12+ jurisdictions with more pending. Fair workweek legislation, minimum wage variation across 50+ state/local jurisdictions, break and meal period rules, and overtime calculations create a compliance minefield. Wage theft claims exceed $15B annually (Economic Policy Institute), with scheduling violations a growing category. Immigration enforcement is intensifying: E-Verify mandates expanding, I-9 audit volume increasing, and NAICS 56 (particularly 5617 and 5616) has disproportionate immigrant workforce exposure. Credential and certification tracking adds another layer — security guards need state licensing, healthcare staffing requires credential verification, construction workers need OSHA certifications. Current workforce management solutions (UKG, ADP, Deputy) handle scheduling but lack AI-driven compliance automation. The gap: when a manager creates a schedule, AI should automatically flag: predictive scheduling violations, overtime threshold approaches, break period compliance, credential expirations, and I-9 re-verification deadlines. AI-driven demand forecasting (predicting staffing needs from foot traffic, weather, events) can reduce overstaffing 10-15% while maintaining compliance.

models.name: AI Route Optimization & Dynamic Dispatch

falsification_criteria: Horizontal platform (Salesforce/Microsoft/Google) adds vertical-specific AI features matching specialist depth

models.cla_rationale: Route optimization is a mature category with strong incumbents: Descartes (acquired PC*Miler), Trimble (ALK Technologies), ORTEC, Omnitracs, Locus (last-mile optimization). However, AI-native dynamic optimization (real-time re-routing based on traffic, weather, road closures, loading dock availability) is still nascent -- most existing tools do STATIC route planning, not DYNAMIC dispatch. The AI opportunity: ingest real-time signals (traffic, weather, customer receiving hours, driver HOS remaining, fuel prices by station) and continuously re-optimize routes throughout the day. The biggest value creation is in reducing EMPTY MILES: 28% of US truck miles are driven empty (deadhead). AI matching of backhaul loads and continuous route optimization can reduce deadhead to 15-20%, saving $25-50B annually across the industry.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=logistics_optimization, buyer=mid_enterprise, frag=6, tam_source=parsed $100000M
models.deep_dive_evidence: US commercial trucking: 15.5M registered vehicles. Average truck drives 100K-120K miles/year. Fuel cost at $4/gallon on 6 MPG = $67-80K/year per truck. 28% empty miles = $100B+ in wasted fuel and capacity. Current route optimization adoption: 45% of large carriers (500+ trucks) use some form, but only 12% use AI-native dynamic optimization. Small carriers (<20 trucks): <5% use route optimization software. Diesel prices volatile: $3.50-5.50/gallon range since 2022. EV trucks introduce new optimization parameters (charging station location, battery range degradation, time-of-use electricity pricing). The dual-fleet transition (ICE + EV) creates complexity that AI is uniquely positioned to manage: which truck gets which route based on range requirements, charging infrastructure, and delivery deadlines. Route optimization for EV commercial fleets is essentially a new category with no incumbents.

But the business operations side is primitive: most creators manage finances through spreadsheets, lack proper rights tracking, and overpay on taxes. The typical mid-tier creator (100K-1M followers) manages 3-5 revenue streams (ad revenue, sponsorships, merchandise, subscriptions, licensing) across 2-4 platforms with zero integrated financial visibility. AI creator business tools secured $300M+ in funding in 2025. The Coasean thesis applies directly: a creator who previously needed a 5-person team (manager, agent, accountant, lawyer, social media manager) can potentially operate with AI + 1 human coordinator. This is the full-service-replacement architecture: replacing the agency model with an AI-native operations platform. This extends the existing PC8-FSR-TALENT-01 and PC8-FSR-INDARTIST-01 model cards with deeper business operations scope and evidence.

models.name: Government Constituent Services AI Agent Platform

models.cla_rationale: Government constituent services is split between federal (FORTIFIED — dominated by Maximus $5.2B, GDIT, Alorica) and local (ACCESSIBLE — 90K units, minimal vendor lock-in). At the federal level, Maximus operates the CMS Medicare helpline, SSA contact center, and IRS overflow — replacing these contracts requires cleared facilities, FISMA compliance, and multi-year procurement. MO is 6 weighted across tiers. At the local level, most 311 systems are rudimentary (often just a phone number routed to a dispatcher). AI chatbots and voice agents can serve as the first-ever scalable constituent service layer for small municipalities. Salesforce Public Sector and ServiceNow are expanding into government constituent services but targeting large agencies. The mid-market (cities 10K-250K population, counties, school districts) is underserved. models.deep_dive_evidence: US government entities handle an estimated 2B+ citizen contacts annually across all channels (NASCIO 2024). Federal: IRS received 290M calls in FY2023, answered 36%. SSA received 72M calls, answered 52%. VA received 98M calls. State: DMVs, tax agencies, benefits offices handle 500M+ contacts. Local: 311 systems in 400+ cities process 100M+ requests. The citizen service experience is broadly awful: average IRS hold time 28 minutes, SSA 33 minutes, state DMV 45+ minutes in-person. Government contact center staffing is 25-35% below authorized levels due to low pay ($30-38K for GS-5 level) and competition from private sector. AI can address this: (1) conversational AI handles 60-80% of informational queries (hours, locations, status checks, how-to guides) without human intervention, (2) AI triage routes complex cases to the right specialist (reducing transfers, which account for 35% of call handle time), (3) multilingual AI serves 67M US residents who speak a language other than English at home. The federal contact center market is dominated by Maximus ($5.2B, operates 60+ government contact centers with 35K agents), but Maximus is a LABOR company — its model depends on hiring thousands of low-wage call center workers. AI agents directly threaten this model. At the local level, companies like Citibot (311 AI chatbots), PublicInput (civic engagement), and Polco are early movers but tiny ($5-20M revenue).

models.cla_rationale: Market openness is high because 80%+ of affected farms have no digital traceability system and the Jan 2026 deadline is imminent. models.deep_dive_evidence: FDA FSMA Section 204(d) Traceability Rule: effective January 20, 2026, requires additional traceability records for foods on the Food Traceability List (FTL). FTL includes: leafy greens, tomatoes, peppers, melons, sprouts, tropical tree fruits, fresh herbs, shell eggs, nut butters, fresh-cut fruits/vegetables, finfish, crustaceans, molluscan shellfish, and ready-to-eat deli salads. Affected entities: ~45,000 farms + 175,000 packers/distributors/retailers. Compliance requires: Key Data Elements (KDEs) at each Critical Tracking Event (CTE) -- essentially, who had what lot of food, when, where, and what they did with it. Current industry state: 80%+ of small/mid-size farms use paper-based or spreadsheet traceability. Average recall response time: 7-14 days to trace contaminated product to source (2023 FDA recall data). Target: <24 hours source identification. Key players: FoodLogiQ (acquired by Controlant, $100M+), Trustwell (FoodLogiQ parent), IBM Food Trust (blockchain, largely abandoned by IBM), Walmart/Hyperledger (mandated blockchain traceability for leafy greens suppliers in 2023). Startup opportunity: GS1-compliant traceability SaaS for the 45K farms that MUST comply by Jan 2026 but lack any digital system. At $200-$500/month per farm, the immediate compliance TAM is $108M-$270M/year. Expand to packers/distributors for $500-$2,000/month: $1.05B-$4.2B addressable.

BlueCart was acquired by US Foods; xtraCHEF was acquired by Toast — confirming category value but removing independents. Integration with distributor APIs, POS waste tracking, and menu engineering creates deep embedding. Value Density is moderate (6): $300-800/month ARPU from multi-unit operators; value proposition is 5-15% food cost reduction on 28-35% of restaurant revenue going to COGS. Demand Visibility is proven (8): food cost inflation (+5-8% in 2024-2025) and labor shortages driving urgent need for waste reduction and procurement efficiency.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Restaurant inventory management software market projected to reach $9.17B by 2030 from $3.95B in 2024 (GlobeNewsWire, 15% CAGR). USDA estimates US restaurants waste 30-40% of food purchased, totaling $162B in annual losses. For a restaurant with $1M in revenue and 30% food cost ($300K), reducing waste by 10% saves $30K/year — often the difference between profit and loss at 3-9% net margins. QCEW data: NAICS 722 has $322.7B in total annual wages across 703K establishments, with food costs adding another $300-400B. The supply chain is uniquely fragmented: 1,000+ food distributors, 150,000+ food manufacturers, wildly variable pricing. Sysco ($76B revenue) and US Foods ($37B) together control ~35% but use pricing opacity as a profit tool. AI-powered procurement can aggregate purchasing data across thousands of independent restaurants to identify price discrepancies, predict demand (reducing over-ordering), and optimize menus for food cost (menu engineering). The regulatory tailwind is real: California SB 1383 requires 75% reduction in organic waste by 2025, creating compliance pressure. Food service contractors (722310, growing 11.6% YoY) represent a concentrated buyer segment — Compass Group, Aramark, and Sodexo collectively operate 50,000+ kitchens.

models.name: AI Staffing Marketplace — Enterprise Direct Sourcing Platform

models.cla_rationale: Market openness is high because traditional staffing firms (Robert Half, ManpowerGroup, Randstad) are structurally disadvantaged — their business model depends on the markup that AI eliminates. Existing digital platforms (Upwork $690M revenue, Fiverr, Toptal) focus on freelancers, not enterprise staffing replacement. The gap between 'freelance marketplace' and 'enterprise staffing replacement' is where the opportunity lives. Moat advantage is moderate — data on placement outcomes compounds over time (which placements succeed, which fail, why), but talent marketplaces face multi-homing problem (candidates list on multiple platforms). Value density high: enterprise staffing contracts are $50K-500K annual per account. Demand visibility is proven — $200B+ market with incumbents visibly declining.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=marketplace, buyer=multi, frag=8, tam_source=parsed $290000M
models.deep_dive_evidence: The US staffing industry generates $290B+ annually (Staffing Industry Analysts, growing at 2.2% CAGR to 2030). The industry's structural economics are under assault: traditional staffing agencies charge 25-50% markups on hourly rates for candidate sourcing, screening, and employer-of-record services. AI-powered matching can perform sourcing and screening at near-zero marginal cost. Robert Half (RHI) stock declined 53% from peak and ManpowerGroup (MAN) declined 44% — these are the market pricing in structural disruption, not cyclical weakness. IT staffing aggregate revenue is down 9% with larger firms suffering most. The direct sourcing model allows enterprises to build their own curated talent pools, bypassing staffing agency intermediation. Beeline's acquisition of MBO Partners (June 2025) signals enterprise VMS platforms moving into direct sourcing. 65% of recruiters have already implemented AI tools (DemandSage), primarily for candidate sourcing (58% use case), time savings (44%), and cost reduction (30% per hire). The freelance platforms market is $5.6B in 2024 growing to $14.4B by 2030 (Grand View Research, 17.7% CAGR). But this understates the opportunity: the real TAM is the delta between the $200B+ staffing market and the 25-50% markup that AI eliminates — roughly $50-100B in intermediation value at risk. Even capturing 10-15% of this displacement represents a $5-15B market for AI-native staffing platforms.

models.name: Intermodal Optimization & Visibility Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered intermodal freight optimization platform balancing truck-rail-ship modal selection for shippers in the $27.5-54B US intermodal market growing at 11.7-13.5% CAGR to $78.9-93.5B by 2030
falsification_criteria: Horizontal platform (Salesforce/Microsoft/Google) adds vertical-specific AI features matching specialist depth
Customer acquisition cost exceeds 18-month payback period in target segment
Autonomous vehicle deployment timeline extends 5+ years beyond current projections
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
models.cla_rationale: Intermodal optimization sits between two oligopolies: Class I railroads (7 companies, 94% of freight rail revenue) and large trucking carriers. J.B. Hunt is the dominant intermodal player ($6.5B intermodal revenue, 100K+ containers). Traditional intermodal brokers/IMCs (Hub Group, STG Logistics, XPO) handle modal selection manually. The AI opportunity is DYNAMIC modal optimization: for any given shipment, should it move truck-only, rail-truck, or rail-truck-rail based on real-time pricing, capacity, transit time, carbon emissions, and weather? Current technology: most shippers use static routing rules, not dynamic optimization. The platform that can ingest live rail capacity (from all 7 Class I railroads) and truck capacity (from 500K+ carriers) and optimize in real-time wins. MO is 6 because J.B. Hunt and Hub Group have strong intermodal positions but lack AI optimization depth.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=supply_chain_optimization, buyer=enterprise, frag=6, tam_source=parsed $50000M
models.deep_dive_evidence: US intermodal volumes: 14.8M containers/trailers moved in 2024. Rail intermodal is 3.5x more fuel efficient than over-the-road trucking. EPA Scope 3 emissions reporting requirements are driving corporate shippers to track and reduce transportation emissions -- rail intermodal is the easiest way to show 40-60% CO2 reduction per shipment. Driver shortage makes intermodal structural: one train replaces 280 trucks. Class I railroad on-time performance improved to 75-85% (up from 60-70% during 2021-2022 service crisis), making intermodal viable for time-sensitive freight again. Key pain point: intermodal transit time variability. AI can predict actual transit time (not published schedule) based on rail congestion, weather, terminal dwell time -- reducing variability from +/- 2 days to +/- 0.5 days. This predictability unlocks $50B+ of freight currently moving by truck because shippers cannot accept intermodal variability.

models.name: Commodity Row Crop Precision Input Management Platform
models.one_liner: Field-level prescription engine that ingests yield monitor data, soil EC maps, satellite NDVI, and weather models to generate variable-rate seeding, fertilizer, and lime prescriptions -- reducing input costs $15-40/acre on the 230M acres of US corn and soy
falsification_criteria: If John Deere's Operations Center closes the prescription-to-outcome feedback loop for its 200M+ connected acres, eliminating the independent platform opportunity
If commodity prices collapse (corn below $3.50/bu sustained) to the point where farmers cut all precision ag spending to survive
If fertilizer prices normalize to pre-2020 levels, reducing the urgency of input optimization from 'survival' to 'nice-to-have'
models.cla_rationale: Market openness is moderate because Deere Operations Center, Climate FieldView (Bayer), and Corteva Granular all compete in prescription generation. But none has closed the feedback loop, and all are mistrusted as seed/chemical company subsidiaries. An INDEPENDENT platform (not owned by an input company) has structural trust advantage. Moat advantage builds through acre-years of verified outcome data. Value density is moderate per-acre ($3-8/acre) but massive at scale (230M acres addressable). Demand is proven: FBN's $900M+ fundraising demonstrates farmer willingness to pay for independent agronomic intelligence.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=data_compounding, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: US corn: 94.6M planted acres (2024 USDA), avg input cost $750/acre (seed $130, fertilizer $250, crop protection $80, fuel/equipment $160, land $130). Soy: 86.1M acres, avg input cost $430/acre. Variable-rate technology (VRT) is adopted on ~30% of corn acres and ~22% of soy acres (USDA ARMS 2023), meaning 125M+ acres are applying uniform-rate inputs despite known sub-field variability -- a $4-8B annual inefficiency. The data compounding moat: every acre-year of yield data correlated with inputs, soil, and weather makes prescriptions more accurate. Climate Corp (acquired by Bayer, formerly Monsanto, for $930M in 2013) attempted this but failed to gain farmer trust due to data privacy concerns and Monsanto association. Granular (acquired by Corteva for ~$300M) has 25M+ managed acres. Farmers Business Network (FBN) has 60M+ contributed acres of agronomic data from 60K+ farm members. The key insight: NO PLATFORM has closed the loop from prescription to verified yield outcome at scale. Current tools generate recommendations but do not automatically learn from what actually happened. Closing this feedback loop is the data compounding opportunity. Average ROI per trial: $22-38/acre on corn (Iowa State On-Farm Network, 2019-2024 average), $12-20/acre on soy. At $3-8/acre subscription price, payback is 3-5x in year one.

models.name: Ag Labor Management & H-2A Compliance Platform
models.one_liner: End-to-end seasonal farm labor platform: H-2A visa petition filing, DOL wage compliance, worker housing management, payroll with piece-rate/hourly blending, and crew scheduling -- serving 17,000+ H-2A employer agents filing 378K worker petitions annually in the most complex labor compliance environment in US agriculture
falsification_criteria: If comprehensive immigration reform creates a new agricultural visa category that is simpler than H-2A, reducing the compliance complexity that drives software demand
If H-2A program growth stalls or reverses due to political restrictions on legal immigration
If Seso achieves dominant market position (>30% of H-2A filings), closing the window for new entrants
models.cla_rationale: Market openness is high: Seso is the only funded startup in this space, serving 2,000 of 17,600+ H-2A employers (11%). 89% of the market is unserved by any software platform. Moat advantage is strong because H-2A regulatory complexity creates deep domain expertise barriers (DOL, USCIS, OSHA housing standards, state-specific wage rules). Once a farm runs payroll and compliance through the platform, switching costs are extremely high (mid-season switch = compliance risk). Value density is high: $5-15K/year per farm employer is a fraction of the $50K-$500K penalty risk for non-compliance. Demand visibility is exceptional: H-2A is growing 12-15% annually by DOL data, creating a growing market with compounding urgency.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=vertical_saas, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: H-2A Temporary Agricultural Worker Program: 378K certified positions (FY2023), 17,600+ employer applications (DOL OFLC data). Growth rate: 12-15% annually for past 7 years, accelerating as undocumented labor supply tightens. H-2A compliance is EXTREMELY COMPLEX: (1) Adverse Effect Wage Rate (AEWR): set by DOL per state, $14.12-$19.75/hr (2024), must pay higher of AEWR, prevailing wage, or federal/state minimum. (2) Housing: employer must provide free housing meeting OSHA standards to all H-2A workers. (3) Transportation: employer pays inbound/outbound transportation from home country. (4) Three-quarter guarantee: must offer work for at least 75% of contract period. (5) Corresponding workers: domestic applicants get same terms as H-2A workers. Filing cost per worker: $2,000-$4,000 (attorney fees, filing fees, recruitment advertising). Total H-2A compliance cost: $3B-$5B/year industry-wide. Current solutions: immigration attorneys ($300-$500/hr), farm labor contractors (FLCs, who handle compliance for a fee but often poorly), and paper-based record-keeping. NO dominant software platform serves the H-2A lifecycle. AgriLegal is niche. Seso ($50M raised, YC W20) is the emerging leader, handling H-2A filing + payroll + housing management for 2,000+ farms. Farmworker Compliance Solutions (small). The market is structurally growing 12-15%/year because H-2A is the ONLY legal path for seasonal farm labor, and enforcement of I-9/E-Verify is pushing farms from undocumented to H-2A.

models.name: Public Health Surveillance & Response Intelligence Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered disease surveillance and public health response platform integrating hospital data, pharmacy claims, wastewater monitoring, and social signals to enable real-time outbreak detection and resource allocation for 3,000+ local health departments serving 330M Americans

models.falsification_criteria: If CDC Data Modernization Initiative successfully builds a unified national surveillance platform that serves local health departments directly (eliminating the market for third-party platforms). If Palantir expands HHS Protect into a permanent public health intelligence product. If public health funding retracts post-COVID (2024-2025 budget cuts suggest this is already happening in some states). If health data privacy concerns (HIPAA, state laws) prevent the data integration necessary for comprehensive surveillance.
models.cla_rationale: The public health data infrastructure is shockingly fragmented: 54 state/territorial health departments and 3,000+ local health departments each run independent surveillance systems, most based on 1990s-era architecture. CDC's BioSense Platform, ESSENCE, and NNDSS are federal backbone systems that are underfunded and under-integrated. Palantir deployed HHS Protect during COVID ($90M+ contract) proving the concept, but the platform was an emergency deployment, not a sustainable product. MO is 6 because the federal layer has incumbent presence (Palantir, IBM, MITRE) but the 3,000 local health departments are essentially greenfield — most use Excel and manual reporting. MA is 8 because longitudinal health surveillance data creates compounding intelligence (each season of flu, each outbreak, each vaccination campaign improves models). DV is 8: post-COVID, every state legislature has funded public health modernization bills.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=data_compounding, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: COVID exposed fatal gaps in US public health surveillance: CDC received COVID case reports via FAX and manual data entry from states. The $2.1B CDC Data Modernization Initiative (2020-2025) is upgrading infrastructure but progress is slow. 3,006 local health departments (NACCHO 2023) serve 330M Americans — median budget $2.8M, median staff 17 FTEs. 75% still use paper-based or spreadsheet-based disease reporting. Wastewater surveillance, proven during COVID (detecting outbreaks 4-7 days before clinical testing), now covers 1,400+ sites through NWSS but lacks AI-powered analytics at most sites. Hospital data integration: ONC/CMS interoperability mandates (TEFCA) create new data flows but no intelligence layer exists to synthesize them. The INFORMED platform (Innovation Network for Fusion of Real-time Disease Surveillance) at Johns Hopkins APL demonstrated that AI can detect outbreaks 2-3 weeks earlier than traditional reporting. Pharmacy claims data (200M+ prescriptions/month for antivirals, antibiotics, OTC remedies) is a leading indicator that most health departments cannot access. The AI opportunity: integrate disparate data streams (clinical, wastewater, pharmacy, emergency room, school absenteeism) into a real-time surveillance intelligence platform that gives every local health department CDC-level analytical capability.

models.cla_rationale: Market Openness is strong (7): ComplianceMate (acquired by Emerson), Testo, and Therma (Google-backed) serve portions of the market but no dominant player exists for the full-service compliance stack (temperature monitoring + HACCP documentation + health inspection prep + employee training tracking). 703K food service establishments with only ~15% using automated monitoring = massive greenfield. Moat Advantage is moderate (6): IoT sensor hardware is increasingly commoditized, but the compliance rule engine (different regulations in 50 states + 3,000+ county health departments) and automated documentation create stickiness. Value Density is moderate (5): $100-300/month per location — low ARPU but mandatory spend once regulators enforce. Demand Visibility is proven (8): FDA FSMA enforcement tightening, health department inspection technology modernization, and brand liability concerns (a single foodborne illness outbreak can cost $75K-2M+ per incident) create non-discretionary demand.
